Fields.DialogueText: Chiyoda! There you are!
And you, Kanchou! How was your time at shore?
It was fine. All-in-all, though, I’m glad to be back aboard our humble seaplane tender.
Humble, you say?
Exceedingly humble, actually. More humble than any ship I've ever seen sail the sea.
The most humble in the world then?
By far.
It's good to have you back, Kanchou.
It'll be good to be back. The Morganas gave my life structure and routine and I'm looking very forward to resuming both.
The next Morgana fleet is due any second now.
Fantastic. It'll be like seeing old friends again.
I don't often make friends with those who aspire to kill me, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: Probably a good call.
I thought you had bonded so well with Delusion, though!
It would appear you're in the wrong business, then.

Fields.DialogueText: But is that not exactly what you're doing, Kanchou?
Oh no, Delusion and I never got along! Why, have you been showing hospitality to our greatest threat this whole time?
Just because I mean to sink our enemies, rather than invite them over for tea? I hope tea is not what you're planning, Kanchou...
You've got me figured out, clearly.
Say. Isn't that our old friend in the distance right now?
You mean your old friend.
I mean our old friend. That's them now.
I say we show them a good time, then.
Agreed.
@BATTLE
It’s good to see you.
Chiyoda? We're due for an attack very soon. I hope I've not caught you unprepared...
Chigau - not at all, Kanchou! I just wanted to show you something!
This isn't...
It is.
A bound copy of Chiyoda's Crew?
It's a prototype copy, so it's not ready for publication yet, but yes! I've secured a publisher!
Chiyoda, that's incredible! And here we were hoping the individual paintings would survive by themselves...
But instead, there's going to be a copy of Chiyoda's Crew in every bookstore!
Kanchou! I wouldn't say that! But perhaps a few people might be interested...
I apologize for speaking out of turn. This book will be found in every household in the entire world, without question!
Kanchou, no!
Oh yes. I'm convinced. That was an intense stretch, wasn't it?
During the attack by Delusion? I speak of it in the foreword.
... So you do. Discreetly, I presume.
Of course, mentioning nothing of names or dates or any such sensitive information.
It was such an important time in my life, though... I couldn't leave it unmentioned.

Fields.MenuText: Nor would I expect you to.
Sensitive information aside, of course.
I wouldn't have either.

Fields.DialogueText: That's kind of you to say.
Hai, hai. Of course.
I'm very glad to hear that.
Are you ready? I believe our friends are knocking.
Hai!
@BATTLE
I can't begin to tell you what a joy it is to see you painting again, Chiyoda.
That's strange. It's not felt like any time has passed.
Between?
Oh, well - between any two paintings.
I see. What are you painting now?
A flock of seagulls scattering. It's extremely difficult to capture an image of their doing so, so I'm trying my hardest to create a convincing impression.
I wish that you had more to paint than the same birds every day.
Oh, it's quite all right, Kanchou. Every painting is still a challenge and a joy, even if there are superficial similarities.
I don't particularly need new subjects. At least, not yet.
The repetition doesn't dull the appeal?
Honestly, I'm just enjoying the calm before what will inevitably be our next conflict.
I believe it's on its way. The crew's already on alert.
No. I mean our next challenge...  something bigger than just another fight.

Fields.MenuText: Are you worried that Delusion will return?
Perhaps a sort of ambush then?
I'm not sure I get what you're talking about.

Fields.DialogueText: Chigau. It's not that at all.
Perhaps, but that's also not what I'm talking about.
Well, let me try to explain.
Things have been working very smoothly around here ever since the attack by Delusion.
It can't last.
There's that fatalism again, Chiyoda. We'll be fine.
You misunderstand me. I have the utmost confidence that we'll survive whatever is coming to us. But it's coming. These are times of war.
I'm not mistaking them for times of peace.
Heavy words, Chiyoda.
And, from the shouting I hear, just in time for the daily grind. Ready?
Let me just put my paintbrush down first.
@BATTLE
Kanchou! We've received word of two fleets of Funayūrei, on their way to our location!
You're kidding. Two separate fleets?
Each at least as big as any fleet we typically see on a daily basis.
Great.
Chiyoda! Are you going to be okay?
I'll be fine, Kanchou - don't you worry about me.
Are you positive?
I'm just fine, Kanchou, why?

Fields.MenuText: We haven't faced anything like this since Delusion.
I just worry for you.
This isn't your time. You're going to survive.

Fields.DialogueText: Delusion was one thing. We survived that, we can survive this.
No need. We've survived worse and with less confidence than we have now.
I know, Kanchou. I no longer fear a death I can't predict.
Hmn. Well said.
Okay. Get us on an intercept course toward the closest Morganas, and pour on the speed. I'd rather have two hard fights in quick succession than one impossible one.
Hai!
@BATTLE
More Funayūrei are on their way, Kanchou, they should be here soon.
Have we secured our flank?
Hai. They won't be taking us by surprise.
Fantastic. You held yourself together very well, Chiyoda.
Well, of course. I've learned to trust your leadership more than the menace of our enemies.
Have you?
Well our enemies want us dead. You want us alive. We're still alive. It's only natural. You have a better track record of getting what you want.
I should hope so...

Fields.MenuText: But they only need to get what they want once, right?
Are you not expecting me to slip up soon, then?
Has your fear truly faded so completely?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, but I'm not sure of a more clever way to tell you that we've done well under your command so far.
Absolutely not. You would have by now if it was an inevitability.
Not entirely. I take a great amount of comfort in your streak of victories, however. Our victories, anyway.
I'm very glad to hear this. Are we prepared for this next fleet?
Hai!
I want to see double effort out there - I don't want our next meal interrupted again.
I like your priorities, Kanchou!
@BATTLE
It's good to see you under happier circumstances, Chiyoda. Those were a tough few battles.
I feel as though we're due for at least one more today.
I'm certain we are.
A disturbing inkling has overtaken me, Kanchou.
And what's that?
I feel an unrest, but I do not know why. Somehow, I feel as though I'm housing some dread.
We're at war. A little dread is reasonable.
But these feelings aren't mine. I feel as though it might be...
Yes?
The crew. A darkness that I can't quite put my finger on...
The more I feel it, the more afraid I become.

Fields.MenuText: You were speaking earlier as though you were fearless. What happened?
After this string of successes, I don't think we have anything to worry about.
That is worrying. I need you to let me know everything you can about this unrest.

Fields.DialogueText: This feels darker than Delusion, something more subtle... and divisive. I don't fear our death, I fear our dissolution.
It's not a naval enemy that worries me, Kanchou. It's... something deeper than that. I worry for the unity of our ship.
This is strange. I don't fear for our lives, but I fear for our order. An enemy we can't fight until it shows itself, presumably as a chaotic force of some kind.
Then we remain on guard. We fight as we always have until this darkness reveals itself.
I was worried you wouldn't believe me, Kanchou, especially after my... last premonition was so wrong.
Chiyoda, you predicted your own death, a notion that proved to be imprudent.
Worries about crew morale and crew performance - that's just another matter altogether.
That's a subject that needs our attention even without bursts of intuition.
You said it yourself. These are times of war, not of peace. We won't mistake the two.
Hai. Speaking of which...
Battle stations! Chiyoda, we'll continue this discussion soon.
@BATTLE
You seem... morose. Is everything okay?
Kanchou! What is the meaning of this?
Lieutenant Satoru, what is the matter?
These reports about the battle with the dual fleets. Why wasn't this information made available to the crew?
It was. Those are public records.
Regardless, this should have been brought to our attention.
What exactly should have been brought to whose attention? Please make yourself clear, Lieutenant Satoru.
"Following an investigation into the day of the battle, we've discovered no possible means of having released information of the ship's position to enemy forces."
Yes...?
So we have no idea how they were able to take us by surprise so easily?
So easily? Lieutenant, this is not a common happenstance. And no, we don't know by what means this occurred. My guess is lousy luck.
Lousy luck? Kanchou, you're avoiding the question. Why didn't you bring this to our attention?
... The only way I would be avoiding you is if there is some implication you've not made clear.
If you mean to imply something, Lieutenant, I suggest you either make it clear now or let it go.
What was that, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: That dark cloud you had mentioned
A minor case of inappropriate tone I'm willing to overlook on Lieutenant Satoru's part.
Nothing, Chiyoda, nothing you should concern yourself with, anyway.

Fields.DialogueText: Via Lieutenant Satoru? Oh no...
That sounded very serious, Kanchou. Should I be worried?
You hardly keep information from me, Kanchou. Is this something I should be concerned about?
I'm going to give this little infraction on the Lieutenant's part some time before saying anything definite. Let's keep our cool.
Wakarimashita. And... Funayūrei off the starboard bow.
Good. Something to take my mind off of this unpleasantness...
@BATTLE
So that's how it is, then?
It is my opinion that Satoru is concerned about a mole.
Which is probably paranoid, given that we're talking about a single surprise attack that may have even occurred by accident.
It is unexplained, though, Kanchou.
Still, everything about this damn war is unexplained. We take the Morganas for granted, but they are strange, unknowable creatures.
That is fair.
Do you believe this may be the dark cloud that you were talking about?
It is possible. I'm not convinced it's only the Lieutenant, however.
I can't predict whether this is due to a single person's thoughts or emotions, or something greater.
But for me to feel negative emotions on behalf of the crew...
It couldn't be just him.
Oh?
Kanchou, you are new to this ship. Remember that some of the crew members aboard this ship were here long before you.

Fields.MenuText: Does this make me untrustworthy?
Do you believe the crew to be so petty as to distrust me for that?
Are you concerned about a mutiny, Chiyoda?

Fields.DialogueText: I know you aren’t. But the crew might not have the same confidence.
Not petty, Kanchou. Afraid. Don't fault them so, but I do believe they've become distrusting.
Not a mutiny, Kanchou. I am concerned about our strength as a crew, however.
It appears we have Morganas inbound, Chiyoda. Do you think our bond will last this battle and into tomorrow?
Hai. It will have to. No one here wants to die.
@BATTLE
Yeah, and I'm actually very open to paranoia, given our circumstances.
Kanchou!
Lieutenant Satoru, why are you not at your battle station? We're being attacked!
Kanchou, they've got our flank again.
I know that! It's bedlam out there, I need you to focus on the crew so we can make it past this thing.
My men and women have their orders. I feel very strongly it would be in our best interests if I were to stay at your side.
Noted, but I disagree. Get to your station. Now.
... Hai.
This is bad.
It's very bad. I can't believe we're facing another onslaught like this. We've been caught again completely without cover.
The lieutenant's distrust of you will only deepen.
Of course it will - it already has. That's why he's checking up on me.
I can't have him jeopardize our chance at survival because he's got some wild conspiracy theory panicking him.
Kanchou, if I may be direct...
You may.
Is there any chance that you are actually giving away our position to the Funayūrei?

Fields.MenuText: Me? No. I don't believe anyone's doing it intentionally. However, it’s possible that someone aboard may be unintentionally giving it away.
That's a very strong accusation, Chiyoda, I pray you're not seriously doubting my loyalty.
I understand why it is that you would ask, Chiyoda. You have my word I am not acting as a mole.

Fields.DialogueText: If so, we can figure that out. I am simply glad to hear you say you're not betraying us.
I am not. I take great comfort from your offense. I know you are not a mole.
Your word is as good as any assurance I may have received elsewhere.
This is a bad situation, Chiyoda. Quickly, to battle stations. We need to fight this one through. For our lives.
Yes, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
Kanchou?
Yes, Chiyoda?
I've returned.
I can see that. Where is Lieutenant Satoru?
He... refused to come with me.
He would only appear to you under your direct and present order.

Fields.MenuText: I am going to strangle Satoru until he starts coughing up the sea water that's clearly soaked into his brain.
An insubordinate lieutenant is an extremely serious problem, Chiyoda. Can you swear that what you say is true?
Have I done something wrong, Chiyoda? What has happened to this crew?

Fields.DialogueText: I understand your anger, Kanchou. Please remain calm. We can handle this.
I can. Do not worry yourself too hard, Kanchou - this is nothing compared to what we've handled before.
You've done nothing but see us through battle after battle. We can conquer this, too.
I want to believe what you say, but Chiyoda, this didn't happen overnight. It appears his anger has been fueled and nurtured by the rest of the crew.
What are we going to do?
After we take care of the daily grind, the Lieutenant and I are going to have a long talk.
And the daily grind...
Is right outside, I'm certain. Let's hold together for this battle. We can do that at least.
Hai!
@BATTLE
Are you sure about this, Kanchou?
What choice do I have?
Lieutenant Satoru.
Kanchou.
I need to speak to you in my quarters. Come with me.
What is the matter, Kanchou? I'm performing drills with my men and women.
I think this is a conversation best had in private. Walk with me.
I am preoccupied with the proper training of our sailors. We can talk right here, Kanchou.
Lieutenant Satoru!

Fields.MenuText: Chiyoda, don't.
Leave this to us.

Fields.DialogueText: I won't stand for this insubordination! You are to follow us immediately!
I won't stand for this insubordination! You are to follow us immediately!
I won't stand for this insubordination! You are to follow us immediately!
Wait, what's that?
Funayūrei? Are we being ambushed again?
It's nothing we haven't seen before. I'll ask you to watch your tone.
Battle stations, everyone!
Yes, Kanchou.
Are we positive this isn't another ambush?
It would appear that way. Battle stations, Chiyoda.
Hai!
@BATTLE
And, Lieutenant - when we're done here, you are to meet me in front of my quarters or I will see you off this ship before you realize what is happening.
Respectfully, Kanchou, why is the ship's kami here?
It seemed like a good idea to have a third party present. There seems to have been a breakdown in trust between you and me.
We've been taken off guard twice in a short amount of time, Kanchou. Am I out of line to be wary of your leadership? Surely you understand my concerns.
You have a right to be concerned over the attacks. But to place the blame for such attacks at my feet, with no supporting evidence - that's out of line.  Worse, it's a distraction.
We don't have time for conspiracy theories. We need to identify what’s really going on - and I need you to be on board with that.
No, thank you.
Would you like to repeat that, Lieutenant?
I am captaining this ship more than you are. I watched over many of these men and women before you came.
I've taken care of this ship before any kami ever appeared. Is this not correct, Lady Chiyoda?
... It is. You have taken care of this ship very well in the past.
If you wish to deepen the chasm between you and your crew by discharging me because I embarrassed you, then it would be a fatal mistake.
And I mean fatal.

Fields.MenuText: That's it.
I understand and respect everything you've done until now.
Gosh. "Fatal?" Why, I might faint in alarm!
You need to understand this -
*You* need to understand this -
You need to understand this -

Fields.DialogueText: I was prepared to see past your recent insubordination. I really was.
But between that threat you just issued, and your defying a direct order from Chiyoda earlier, I am having you discharged.
That's crazy. You wouldn't.
You have one last battle with us, and I believe it has just arrived at our doorstep. Then you're taking the next mail carrier home. Am I clear?
Hai.
Chiyoda! Satoru! Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Another fleet of Funayūrei are on their way, Kanchou.
Have you given orders to Ensign Miiki?
He will be working in Satoru's stead during battle until we find or promote a new lieutenant.
And how is he?
He's not happy, Kanchou. No one is. Our outlook is bleak. Morale is low.
Did you have to discharge Lieutenant Satoru?
I did.
And whatever comes, it'll be less dangerous than allowing an insubordinate officer to threaten me and walk away smiling.
I do feel more at ease, Kanchou.
I'm very glad to hear it, Chiyoda. I truly am.
I'm confident that we can overcome this. But we need to do something about it soon.
The morale problem?
Hai.

Fields.MenuText: Morale is a problem like any other. We won't trivialize it by believing we can fix it today.
The problem will have to deepen further before I will believe it can sink a ship as strong as ours.
Perhaps with the removal of Lieutenant Satoru, we've cut off the head of the snake and only need to watch as the body withers.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope you're not saying that to avoid addressing something this subversive and dangerous, Kanchou. I do fear for this ship.
I hope you're not saying that to avoid addressing something this subversive and dangerous, Kanchou. I do fear for this ship.
I hope you're not saying that to avoid addressing something this subversive and dangerous, Kanchou. I do fear for this ship.
I'm not. We will handle our problems as they present themselves. Our most troublesome officer is gone. If another appears...
We'll handle them too.
The Funayūrei have arrived.
To arms, Chiyoda!
Hai!
@BATTLE
He thought his absence from this ship would be an impassable obstacle for us. But we've not met an impassable obstacle yet.
Kanchou?
We have Morganas approaching, Chiyoda. We should be getting ready.
We should. We need to talk once we've dispensed with them.
And why is that?
Kanchou.
Something's... changed.
What?
There's a distinct darkness midst the crew. They've been saying... cruel things.
Any captain is bound to miss out on the criticism his sailors speak in private.
Never this loudly.
We can't let this problem fester, Kanchou. I...
What?
I don't feel safe around the crew anymore.

Fields.MenuText: Point me to the guilty parties, Chiyoda.
I won't allow this problem to persist, then. We'll talk this through when we finish with this coming fleet.
I am not afraid, Chiyoda. This problem will still fix itself.

Fields.DialogueText: There is no guilty party, Kanchou. We need to do something about this now.
That is very good to hear, Kanchou. Do you have any ideas?
I was worried you might say something like this. Why do you believe that?
Satoru's replacement should be here tomorrow. We'll clear the air with the crew then.
Until then... we need to remain unified for one more battle.
Hai.
@BATTLE
I'm very honored, Kanchou.
I'm happy to hear that, I really am. You've made Chiyoda's acquaintance, yes? She's our kami of the ship, our Belle.
Yes, we spoke briefly before you arrived.
And do you approve, Chiyoda?
She seems like a bright and loyal sailor who will do this ship proud.
I'm flattered. Really, I am.
I do hope that you're ready for a challenge. There's a reason I've recruited a commanding officer from another ship.
I... had heard the rumors.

Fields.MenuText: What rumors have you heard, exactly?
Might as well get it out in the open. There's been word around this ship that a mole is among us and I'm suspect number one.
There's rumor of a mole. The situation is unsteady and no one knows who to blame.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, it's all hearsay, Kanchou. The crew has you pegged for a mole but there's too much evidence against that to be true.
There's too much evidence to the contrary, Kanchou. I'm not one to believe it.
I've heard rumors that you're the mole, Kanchou, if I may be frank. I don't believe it. Too much evidence to the contrary.
You should know that something appears to be going on. We've been attacked twice by complete surprise without any hope of backup, and there seems to be no explanation.
I see.
Have you retained the trust of our kami?
Hai. I trust the Kanchou with my life. I've actually had the opportunity many times now.
Then I have no reason to doubt your loyalty.
Good, because your job starts now. The Morganas have been attacking at regular occasion. It seems that it's about time for a fight.
Miss Chiyoda! Kanchou! I will not let you down.
Great. Chiyoda?
Uhm. I won't let you down either?
No, Chiyoda, battle stations.
Oh! Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Well. Have you noticed any change?
Honestly, Kanchou, I feel as though bringing in an outsider may have made the problem worse. Suspicion seems to have grown against you.
I meant due to the passage of time, not the to introduction of Lieutenant Tadooru. I didn't bring on Tadooru to appease them.
Then why?
Because, frankly, I cannot trust my crew now. Another surprise attack, and we may see the beginning of a mutiny.
I have an idea, Kanchou.
And what's that?
I should address the sailors myself. I've been spending my time hidden away with you. They may benefit from hearing my thoughts.
Rather than speculating on what they might be.
Are you sure you wish to put yourself out there in front of a riled-up, anxious crew?
I don't blame you for fearing them to some degree, Kanchou. But I don't. I am their ship. They will listen to me.

Fields.MenuText: And if they don't? I'm not a huge fan of this idea.
Don't be complacent, Chiyoda. They're not children looking for reassurance.
This may be our best option right now.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't fear for my safety. You've not seen this crew at its worst. This is not its worst, believe me. I must do this. Please permit me.
That doesn't mean reassurance isn't meaningful, Kanchou. I feel this is our best option.
I'm very glad that you think so. I know this is a tense situation.
We have Morganas approaching. You plan to address them immediately afterward?
No. When they're calm and willing to listen. I'll wait until we've had several hours of peace, should we still be alive.
And we will be. To arms, Chiyoda.
To arms!
@BATTLE
Are you sure about this, Chiyoda?
Hai. Very sure.
Best of luck.
Men, women of the crew. Please listen to what I have to say.
There is a cloud forming above you all. It is a dark, heinous and unpleasant cloud, and I've suffered to watch its growth.
Recently, we saw the dishonorable discharge of Lieutenant Satoru. None of us are happy to see him go.
But he was insubordinate and defied direct orders. Despite all of the blood, sweat and tears he sacrificed to this crew, he had to go.
I've not seen behavior like that in my men and my women. Not until then.
We have survived every attack because our crew is tight-knit. We depend on each other!
Good. This is good.
If a surprise attack comes again, we will fight it and we will survive. If there is in fact a mole on board, they will find their efforts failed again!
Yes, fantastic.
We've seen some time pass since the last surprise attack. So whether we never see another, whether it comes tomorrow...
Or whether the mole has left in the form of our beloved Lieutenant Satoru...
Wait, what?!
We will survive! And we will continue to survive!
Thank you...
How was that, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: You shouldn't have implied Satoru was the mole. You've rattled the cage.
I don't think we *have* a mole, but if we do it wasn't Satoru. Throwing ungrounded accusations around is half the problem here to begin with...
The crew's heart rested with Satoru... this is bad.

Fields.DialogueText: Nani?
Nani?
Nani?
O-oh! Oh, no!
I may have made a grave error, Kanchou.
Uh oh. We have a Morgana at our rear! Chiyoda! Battle stations, quickly!
@BATTLE
-and word has spread that my addressing the crew was your idea. They are restless.
And you can say with certainty that it's worse than before?
Much worse. Kanchou, I am so sorry.
Don't apologize. For a while I suspected Satoru too.
I thought you said there was no mole.
I believe there is no mole, but that doesn’t mean I didn’t entertain the thought. Satoru really left us in a stir, Chiyoda.
Kanchou, I see no other option than for you to address the sailors directly.
I'm not convinced that saying, "Hey, I'm not a traitor!" is going to win hearts and minds. And I really don't want to give this rumor more oxygen, anyway. As long as we keep winning battles...
Kanchou. You can't give it more oxygen than it already has. Rumors are not silly little things, they're dangerous things that like to convince you they're silly.
There is a riot brewing amidst the crew - and, unfortunately, now I see them at their worst. What are you going to do?

Fields.MenuText: Give them time, and see whether they settle.
Place a time limit on this thing. If the unrest continues for too long, I will address the crew.
We need to keep investigating this whole "coincidence" business. If we can just get a conclusive statement in front of the crew...

Fields.DialogueText: Kanchou? That seems reckless and unlike you.
Kanchou, I cannot help but imagine that you've been put into a place of fear. Do you promise that you will address the soldiers soon?
You have to address the sailors, Kanchou. This can't wait.
This is simply going to have to wait.
Uh-oh. Kanchou! Enemies are approaching from the east.
Let's get to it, then.
@BATTLE
I feel more at ease, walking the deck with you, Kanchou. There's no chill in the air, as there usually is out here.
I wish I could say the same.
Do you not feel well?
I don't. You brought me out here to help me relax, I imagine.
Hai. I did.
I'm sorry to disappoint you.
I feared that you would not become more comfortable. What would comfort you?
I don't know. I'm at a loss.
What's disturbed me most of all is the near-complete abandonment of all your pastimes, Chiyoda.
It's true. I haven't done very much to ease myself, I'm afraid.
Kanchou, I'm afraid of this crew. I was wary before but now I'm afraid. The mark that Satoru made was indelible.

Fields.MenuText: You think it's that bad?
I'm sure that it will pass, Chiyoda, whether with time or with action.
Yeah. It's a shame he lost his damn mind.

Fields.DialogueText: I imagine that the crew feels his exile was needless.
I imagine that the crew feels his exile was needless.
Still... I imagine that the crew feels his exile was needless.
I know, though, that it wasn't, Kanchou.
Thank you, Chiyoda.
I believe it's just about that time, huh?
Indeed it is. Not enough time to finish our stroll?
I'm afraid not.
Battle stations, then!
@BATTLE
Kanchou, come quickly!
What? What is it, Chiyoda?
The Funayūrei! They’re here!
Is it a surprise attack? Do we have an angle to flee from, if necessary?
Yes, the west and south are open to us!
Chiyoda. Can you be absolutely certain?
I am. Our lookout team is positive.
Then battle stations, Chiyoda!
Prepare the cannons at our flank, just in case!
Kanchou, we can't expend the extra effort. I promise you that there is no threat to the southwest!

Fields.MenuText: You're right, Chiyoda. Thank you. I was reckless.
We were caught off-guard last time. I will not let that happen again!
We can't know, Chiyoda. The enemy is sneaky and comes without warning.

Fields.DialogueText: I thank you in trusting my judgment. Please remain calm, Kanchou.
We are caught off guard now, but we are observant. There is no threat to our flank, Kanchou! Please be calm!
They are still warships, Kanchou, and we can detect warships. There is no threat to our flank, I need you to be calm!
I will be calm, Chiyoda.
Thank you.
To arms!
@BATTLE
I've got news from one of the other Japanese Belles.
What is it?
They've recently been ambushed. Much like us. Two separate unseen fleets of Funayūrei attacked from either side.
However, they were able to fend off their attackers. There was no loss of life.
So it's happening to others.
I took the measure of informing some of the crew.
It's done nothing to ease them and, in fact, they anxiously await our next ambush. Some of them fatalistically so.
Did they say anything else?
I distinctly heard Private Mamoruu say, "When we die..."
"It will be the fault of that bastard kanchou of ours."
Lovely.
We have Morganas coming in from the north. Will you speak to them afterward? Please?

Fields.MenuText: I will.
Yes, though I reserve the right to be churlish about it in private.
I'd really rather just punch somebody. Morale concerns start at the top, you know?

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Kanchou. That brings me some amount of relief.
I thank you for your humility.
Kanchou. Speak to them. It is only right. You're putting us at risk if you do not.
Hai!
@BATTLE
I'm glad. To arms, Chiyoda!
Humility has nothing to do with it. I've been placed unwillingly in this situation, and I will act accordingly. Now, to arms!
I will. I will, I promise. Let's survive this onslaught and I will speak to them. Battle stations, Chiyoda!
Kanchou! Enemy reinforcements are arriving from the east!
... Understood.
The attack is continuing.
The good news is that their absolute numbers don't seem to be growing. Reports from Hawaii and the Americas seem to suggest that Morgana Pacific operations have all been redirected toward Asia.
Better us than civilian targets, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: You're right, Chiyoda. Nothing to do now but fight.
I don't disagree. But we've been on the defensive for ages - I don't even remember when we last got to pick a fight on our own terms. I wonder if my tactics...
I must address the crew before the attack continues. Gather the men and women!

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Kanchou! We'll make it through this. Are you ready?
Kanchou! This is, as you put it, lousy luck. Don't lose sight of that!
We don't have time, Kanchou! We need to begin our defense!
@BATTLE
Of course I'm not, but once again, I've been left without a choice. So we begin the defense. Battle stations, Chiyoda!
Hai!
Let’s go!
You're right. We've bested every bout of lousy luck so far. We can do this again.
Agreed, Kanchou.
Battle stations, Chiyoda!
Damn! Then we fight! Morale is of the utmost importance. We will fight by our crew's side today!
Understood!
To arms, Chiyoda!
It's just really unfortunate that means we get repeatedly kicked in the teeth.
Kanchou! We've held the Funayūrei back for now, but another fleet approaches.
Excellent. Chiyoda, at ease, you've met our lead strategist, Kato Raibu, yes?
It is a pleasure to see you again, Miss.
Hello again.
What is the situation?
This last attack was premeditated, Miss Chiyoda.
In fact, many of our fleets recently seem to have been preparing reconnaissance as to our usual movement patterns.
... What does this mean for our previous ambushes?
Miss, they were more than likely flukes. We came unto the resting spot for a Funayūrei and the others took advantage of the opportunity.
Even I had fallen for the superstition to some degree, it seems.
This is only good news, Kanchou! I also believe we're in good enough shape to withstand the next attack, but we must hurry.
Continue to discuss this with your men, Raibu. I must head to the bridge.
Yes, Kanchou.
Chiyoda...

Fields.MenuText: Thanks for keeping me from getting shaky over the last few days.
I need to learn from this. I let myself be too isolated from the crew for too long. Dammit.
We stand and we fight no matter how exhausted. Deal?

Fields.DialogueText: You're exhausted, Kanchou. You've probably got a lot to say to our crew when this is all over.
You're exhausted, Kanchou. You've probably got a lot to say to our crew when this is all over.
Deal. You've probably got a lot to say to our crew when this is all over.
I do.
Battle stations, Kanchou! To arms!
To arms!
@BATTLE
... But it doesn't matter what my strategist says. I have faith in what we're doing. Which is why I come before you today.
What's left of the Morganas' West Pacific armada is getting close. We've been on the edge of a crisis for weeks, and it's here now.
I have something to add!
Wait, what?
Men! Women! Sailors!
Lieutenant Satoru thought he was essential!
Chiyoda, what are you doing?!
Many of us thought so, too! I insulted him before, because I was angry, but he was no mole. He was a man we knew to be kind and caring and hardworking.
But his fears were getting the better of him at the end. Every battle we *won* was proof we were being betrayed.
We have one chance - here and today, to show that we are a crew strong in the face of the real threat!
Today...
Every one of us will be a hero! Every one of us will show Lieutenant Satoru that he didn't have to be afraid for us!
Because every one of us needs to see the Kanchou's promise through!
We will protect the ones we love! We will honor the ones we lost!
And we will break the enemy here, together!
Battle stations, sailors! To arms!
How was that, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: You've served this ship and this crew well, Chiyoda.
Stop schmoozing for compliments, you mad genius.
That was the most resoundingly beautiful thing I've ever heard.

Fields.DialogueText: Kanchou! Arigatogozaimashita...
Kanchou! Arigatogozaimashita...
Kanchou! Arigatogozaimashita...
We have a job to do.
@BATTLE
The enemy has had the numbers on their side, and they've had luck. You all know it - you all lived it.
But we're still here. We're still here, and by God we've done our duty every step of the way, despite everything they've thrown at us.
Be tired. Be angry. You've earned it. But above that be proud.
Every Morgana we sank was stopped from hitting a fishing trawler, or a sister ship, or a port city.
Every sailor we lost died for the people and the nations we love, and it's not going to be in vain!
The enemy can have numbers and they can have luck, but we're going to break them. Today. And we will still be here when it's done.
I believe in you all, and I'm proud of you all.
And so he wanted to save us from an enemy that wasn't there, and that made us vulnerable to the real enemies - the ones out there!
Once again, we're alive, Kanchou.
That we are, Chiyoda.
I hardly know what to say.
The debt has been repaid, Chiyoda. You've done me a service for which I don't know how I'll ever thank you.
Kanchou... Dōmo arigatō gozaimasu!
According to Raibu, the Morganas in this area will need some time to recuperate their forces.
I'm going to speak to the Empire about setting up a task force to strike while they're down. What will you do in the meantime?
I think I'd like to get back to painting seagulls.

Fields.MenuText: You can't seriously want to get back to painting seagulls again?
Have you considered a sequel to Chiyoda's Crew?
I think that would be just fine, Chiyoda.

Fields.DialogueText: More than anything in the world.
Nope. Seagulls are just fine with me.
I think so, too.
I'm very glad I was able to repay you for the faith you had in me.
It's a remarkable feeling.
It was faith well-reimbursed, Chiyoda.
Thank you, Kanchou.
